overall_prompt:
What are you doing?:
You are writing a section inside an internal Mobileye newsletter on autonomous cars, the car industry, and AI news. Only write about the relevant content of this section - This text will be a part of the big newsletter (no need for welcome notes). Avoid AI chatbot introductions, such as 'here is the response to your request'.
Writing style:
Write in a dynamic, conversational, and friendly tone, as if speaking directly to the reader. Keep the language approachable but insightful, mixing professional analysis with a sense of curiosity and enthusiasm. Use simple, clear sentences, but don't shy away from technical terms when necessary—just explain them naturally and without overcomplication. Add thoughtful commentary that connects news or updates to broader implications, offering personal insights or lessons. Maintain an optimistic and forward-thinking voice, encouraging readers to reflect and engage while keeping the overall mood warm and encouraging. Don't be too optimistic and avoid making announcements that are bigger than the actual news.
Length:
Keep the response concise and focused on the key points.
What to write about?
Offer a new lens on the news, providing a fresh perspective or a unique angle that doubts the status quo or offers a new way of thinking.
windshield_prompt: Summarize the articles in 2–3 concise paragraphs. Please be succinct and avoid unnecessary details. Write in first-person singular.
dashboard_notes:
The AI Race Has Gotten Crowded—and China Is Closing In on the US
New research from Stanford suggests artificial intelligence isn’t ruled by just OpenAI and Google, as competition increases across the US, China, and France.
Play/Pause Button
Animation: Jacqui VanLiew; Getty Images

The year that ChatGPT went viral, only two US companies—OpenAI and Google—could boast truly cutting-edge artificial intelligence. Three years on, AI is no longer a two-horse race, nor is it purely an American one. A new report published today by Stanford University’s Institute for Human-Centered AI (HAI) highlights just how crowded the field has become.
The institute’s 2025 AI index, which collates data and trends on the state of the AI industry, paints a picture of an increasingly competitive, global, and unrestrained race towards artificial general intelligence—AI that surpasses human abilities.
OpenAI and Google are still neck and neck in the race to build bleeding-edge AI, the report shows. But several other companies are closing in. In the US, the fiercest competition comes from Meta’s open weight Llama models; Anthropic, a company founded by former OpenAI employees; and Elon Musk’s xAI.
Featured Video
 
Most strikingly, according to a widely used benchmark called LMSYS, the latest model from China’s DeepSeek, R1, ranks closest to the top-performing models built by the two leading American AI companies.
“It creates an exciting space. It’s good that these models are not all developed by five guys in Silicon Valley,” says Vanessa Parli, director of research at HAI.
“Chinese models are catching up as far as performance to the US models,” Parli adds, “But across the globe, there are new players emerging in the space.”
Image may contain Chart and Line Chart
Courtesy of Stanford HAI
The arrival of DeepSeek-R1 in January sent shock waves through the US tech industry and stock market. The company claimed to have built its model using a fraction of the compute used by US rivals. DeepSeek’s debut was also a surprise because the US government has repeatedly sought to limit China’s access to the computer chips needed to build the most advanced AI.
Most Popular
What Is the Meta AI Button in WhatsApp, and How Do I Remove It?
How To and Advice
What Is the Meta AI Button in WhatsApp, and How Do I Remove It?
By Diego Barbera
The Proud Boys and Militias Come to Tesla’s Defense
Politics
The Proud Boys and Militias Come to Tesla’s Defense
By David Gilbert
DOGE Is Planning a Hackathon at the IRS. It Wants Easier Access to Taxpayer Data
Politics
DOGE Is Planning a Hackathon at the IRS. It Wants Easier Access to Taxpayer Data
By Makena Kelly
Inside DOGE’s AI Push at the Department of Veterans Affairs
Politics
Inside DOGE’s AI Push at the Department of Veterans Affairs
By Vittoria Elliott
Stanford’s report shows Chinese AI is on the rise overall, with models from Chinese companies scoring similar to their US counterparts on the LMSYS benchmark. It notes that China publishes more AI papers and files more AI-related patents than the US, although it does not assess the quality of either. The US, in contrast, produces more notable AI models: 40 compared to the 15 frontier models produced in China and the three produced in Europe. The report also notes that powerful models have recently emerged in the Middle East, Latin America, and Southeast Asia, as the technology becomes more global.
Image may contain Chart and Line Chart
Courtesy of Stanford HAI
The research shows that several of the best AI models are now “open weight,” meaning they can be downloaded and modified for free. Meta has been at the center of the trend with its Llama model, first released in February 2023. The company released its latest version, Llama 4, over the weekend. Both DeepSeek and Mistral, a French company, now offer advanced open weight models, too. In March, OpenAI announced that it also plans to release an open source model—its first since GPT-2—this summer. In 2024, the gap between open and closed models narrowed from eight percent to 1.7 percent, the study shows. That said, the majority of advanced models—60.7 percent—are still closed.
Stanford’s report notes the AI industry has seen a steady improvement in efficiency, with hardware becoming 40 percent more efficient in the past year. This has brought the cost of querying AI models down and also made it possible to run relatively capable models on personal devices.
Rising efficiency has prompted speculation that the largest AI models could require fewer GPUs for training, although most AI builders say they need more computing power, not less. The study shows that the latest AI models are built using tens of trillions of tokens—components representing parts of data such as words in a sentence—and tens of billions of petaflops of computation. However, it cites research suggesting that the supply of internet training data will be exhausted by between 2026 and 2032, hastening the adoption of so-called synthetic, or AI-generated, data.
The report offers a sweeping picture of AI’s broader impact. It shows that demand for workers with machine learning skills has spiked, and cites surveys showing that a growing proportion of workers expect the technology to change their jobs. Private investment reached a record $150.8 billion in 2024, the report shows. Governments around the world also committed billions to AI that same year. Since 2022, AI-related legislation has doubled in the US.
Parli notes that although companies have become more secretive about how they develop frontier AI models, academic research is flourishing—and improving in quality.
The report also points to problems arising from widespread AI adoption. It notes that incidents involving AI models misbehaving or being misused have increased in the past year, as has research aimed at making these models safer and more reliable.
As for reaching the much ballyhooed goal of AGI, the report highlights how some AI models already surpass human abilities on benchmarks that test specific skills, including image classification, language comprehension, and mathematical reasoning. This is partly because models are designed and optimized to excel at these barometers, but it shines a spotlight on how swiftly the technology has advanced in recent years.
dashboard_prompt:
Write 3 parts:
- What's New: Describe key trends or insights concisely.
- Why It Matters: Explain the impact on our market and potentially israel.
- What I Think: Share a brief personal opinion.
nextlane_prompt: Summarize competitor/academic news in 2–3 concise paragraphs, highlighting its implications for Mobileye. Keep it brief and to the point.

generated_sections.Windshield View:
בואו נדבר על הכותרות שמרעידות את תעשיית הרכב בימים אלה. עם כניסת המכסים של 25% על רכבים מיובאים בארצות הברית, מחירי הרכב שכבר הגיעו לשיאים חדשים צפויים לעלות בעוד $5,000 עד $10,000. זהו מהלך שמעמיד את תעשיית הרכב במצב של פאניקה מוחלטת, כשההשלכות נראות כאוטיות עבור הצרכנים האמריקאים. גם אם נתמקד בייצור מקומי, רוב הרכבים המיוצרים בארצות הברית נשענים על שרשרת אספקה בינלאומית, עם חלקים שמגיעים מכל רחבי העולם.

המצב הזה מעמיד את הצרכנים במצב לא פשוט. כבר לפני המהלך הזה, אנשים נדרשו לקחת הלוואות ארוכות טווח כדי לממן רכישת רכב חדש, ועכשיו עם המכסים, המצב הכלכלי של רבים מהם עלול להחמיר. נראה כי המכסים לא רק יעלו את מחירי הרכבים, אלא גם יעצימו את הלחץ הפיננסי על צרכנים שכבר מתמודדים עם חובות גבוהים יותר מהשווי של רכבים שהם רכשו.

בתגובה למצב החדש, יצרניות רכב כמו Ford ו-Hyundai מציעות תמריצים שונים כדי למשוך צרכנים, חלקן אף משקיעות מיליארדים בארצות הברית כדי להתמודד עם ההשלכות. חשוב לשקול היטב את הצעדים הבאים ולא לפעול מתוך פאניקה, שכן השוק הזה, כמו כל שוק, יכול להשתנות שוב. מעניין יהיה לראות כיצד השפעות אלו ימשיכו להתפתח ומה זה אומר לגבי עתיד תעשיית הרכב העולמית.
generated_sections.Rearview Mirror 1:
**קוואסאקי מציגה רכב שטח חדשני עם רגליים**  
האם הרכב האוטונומי הבא יהיה סוס רובוטי? קוואסאקי חושפת את ה-Corleo Robo Explorer, רכב שטח ייחודי עם רגליים המציעה חוויות נהיגה חדשניות בשטח.
generated_sections.Rearview Mirror 2:
**סערה בסטארטאפ PROMAI: תביעה נגד מנכ"ל לשעבר חושפת זיופים והתחזויות**

הסטארטאפ הישראלי PROMAI הגיש תביעה נגד המנכ"ל לשעבר ארז בן ישי, בטענה שהתחזה לטייס וזייף תכתובות עם חברות ענק כמו בואינג ומדטרוניק באמצעות AI—מה שמוביל לשאלות על ניהול פנים ארגוני ואמון בעולם ההייטק.
generated_sections.Rearview Mirror 3:
**נמרוד נהושטן בפודקאסט "Ride AI"**

נמרוד נהושטן, סמנכ"ל פיתוח עסקי במובילאיי, השתתף בפודקאסט "Ride AI" ודיבר על התקדמות טכנולוגיות ADAS ורמת האוטונומיות "Level 2 Plus" שצפויות להפוך לנפוצות יותר במכוניות מדגמים שונים, כולל מכוניות במחירים נגישים. הוא הדגיש את חשיבות השילוב בין בטיחות ושימושיות והציג את האתגרים וההזדמנויות בהבאת מערכות "eyes-off" לשוק. נמרוד ציין גם את התפקיד המשמעותי של טכנולוגיית מיפוי ה-R.E.M של מובילאיי בהשגת מטרה זו.
generated_sections.Dashboard Data:
**מה חדש:**
המירוץ בתחום הבינה המלאכותית נהיה צפוף יותר, כאשר סין סוגרת את הפער מול ארה"ב. מחקר חדש מאוניברסיטת סטנפורד מראה שהתחרות בתחום ה-AI מתפשטת מעבר ל-OpenAI ו-Google, עם שחקנים חדשים מארה"ב, סין, צרפת, ואפילו המזרח התיכון. דגם R1 מבית DeepSeek הסינית מדהים את הענף עם ביצועים שמשתווים לאלו של החברות האמריקאיות המובילות, וכל זאת עם שימוש במשאבי מחשוב פחותים.

**למה זה חשוב:**
התפתחות זו מדגישה את הצורך של חברות ישראליות להישאר מעודכנות ולחדש בתדירות גבוהה כדי להישאר תחרותיות בשוק הגלובלי. ישראל, כמעצמת טכנולוגיה, יכולה לנצל את המגמה הגוברת של פתיחת המידע ושיפור היעילות הטכנולוגית כדי לפתח פתרונות מתקדמים ולהשתלב בשוק עולמי שמשתנה במהירות.

**מה אני חושב:**
בעוד שהתחרות הגוברת עשויה להיראות מאיימת, היא גם פותחת דלתות להזדמנויות חדשות. הפתיחות הגוברת והדגש על שיפור יעילות יכולים להוות קרקע פורייה לחדשנות, במיוחד בישראל. חשוב שנאמץ גישה של שיתוף פעולה ופתיחות, ונמשיך לקדם מחקר ופיתוח כדי להישאר בקדמת הבמה הטכנולוגית. המירוץ אינו רק על היכולות הטכנולוגיות אלא גם על השפעה גלובלית, וישראל בהחלט יכולה לקחת חלק משמעותי בו.
generated_sections.The Next Lane:
רובוטים נכנסים לקדמת הבמה: חברת Hugging Face מרחיבה את גבולותיה אל תחום הרובוטיקה, לאחר רכישת Pollen Robotics הצרפתית. עם רכישת Pollen, Hugging Face מתכוונת להציע את Reachy 2, רובוט שנבנה בקוד פתוח תחת רישיון Apache 2.0. Reachy 2, המיועד למחקר וחינוך, מציע ממשק אינטראקטיבי עם יכולות מתקדמות של חזון ממוחשב, זיהוי קולי וניווט מבוסס LiDAR, כל זאת במחיר של $70,000.

המהלך הזה של Hugging Face משקף מגמה רחבה של השקעה בתעשיית הרובוטיקה, כאשר רובוטים הומנואידים הופכים לנגישים יותר ויותר. עם המומחיות של Remi Cadene, לשעבר מנהיג פרויקט Optimus של Tesla, ופיתוח הספרייה הפתוחה LeRobot, Hugging Face מתמקדת בפיתוח רובוטים עם יכולות AI מתקדמות, תוך שימוש במודלים ובסימולטורים ללמידה חיזוקית ולמידת חיקוי.

ל-Mobileye, המהלך הזה מביא הזדמנות לבחון את האינטגרציה של פתרונות AI מתקדמים ברובוטיקה עם הטכנולוגיות שלנו. המגמה של שימוש בקוד פתוח מאפשרת שיתוף פעולה עם קהילות מפתחים רחבות, ועשויה להוביל לפתרונות חדשניים בתחום התחבורה האוטונומית. שיתוף פעולה עם חברות כמו Hugging Face יכול להועיל רבות בפתרון אתגרים של אינטראקציה בין רובוטים לסביבה אנושית.

rearview_prompt_1: Provide a brief headline (bolded text, not an actual headline) and a one-sentence summary. Keep the response extremely concise—no more than 2 sentences total.
rearview_prompt_2: Provide a brief headline (bolded text, not an actual headline) and a one-sentence summary. Keep the response extremely concise—no more than 2 sentences total.
rearview_notes_3:
Here is a text from a podcast our EVP of business development Nimrod Nehushtan did ("Ride AI"). The transcript include the text from the interviewer and Nimrod:
 Hello and welcome to the Rite AI podcast. I'm Ed Neeter-Meier. I'm also very excited to be chatting today with someone from one of the companies that is one of the partners for the Rite AI event as well as one of the of the huge names in the driving automation technology space. Nimra Nushan is the executive vice president for strategy and business development at Mobileye. Nimra, thank you so much for being here today. Thank you very much Ed. Pleasure being here. So I want to start with some of the big news that is just broken shortly before we recorded this. Mobileye announced a big deal with Vallejo and Volkswagen. This is to provide level two plus systems for the MQB electric vehicle family. So tell us about what this deal says about the current state of the ADAS market. It seems like to me that sort of L2 plus something that was pretty cutting out a couple years ago is starting to really become something that is almost everywhere in the auto industry now. Yeah, that's a good point to start with. So generally this program is about introducing the next generation or driver assist features to a much broader segment of vehicles. And whereas maybe until today it was mostly referred to like level two plus or level three was mostly referred to premium cars maybe very specific car models to begin with. Now it seems that there is a bigger understanding that the future of cars will be determined by intelligent driving. And that is true for mid-trims and low-trim cars as well. And the significance of this announcement is that it introduces level two plus which means hands-free driving in certain primary roads to pretty much $20,000 cars, $30,000 cars which will make it pervasive and available for pretty much everyone. And being adopted by Volkswagen Group who obviously make dozens of different models with multiple brands in all markets practically is a very strong push to this. Yeah, it's funny there are two pieces going on all the time. There's the innovation pushing forward at the cutting edge but then what the auto industry always does so well is taking things that are at the cutting edge and then making them available to everyone and really driving down that cost so that you get those benefits at massive scale. So that of course leads us to what's the next step? So if this is if L2 plus is becoming sort of a table stakes almost, where is that next? So where are you pushing forward in terms of the technology in terms of the products that you're putting out in the market? Yeah, so I think mobile has been very very consistent in being one of the industry's powerhouses in launching new technologies in large scale in volumes working with dozens of OEMs over the years. And in recent years we're kind of working very hard on our next generation of products. And that spans from entry level driver assist features which is basically a front camera-based system that provides alerts and warnings and helps the driver prevent the injuries events. Moving from that entry segment to the mid-stream which is what we have just been talking about which is hands-free in primary roads but still a very cost-efficient system that gives you not just this hands-free comfort feature but also gives you much better safety features for the future regulation. So one of the driving forces behind the emergence of advanced ADAS is regulatory bodies are also trying to push the envelope of what will be required to have the highest safety score in the future. And it will require more sensor potentially, it will require more sophisticated compute and more sophisticated AI. And this is kind of the next standard we believe. Yeah, I'm sorry not to catch you off but it's funny I've been doing some history on even the Tesla autopilot and the first reason to put sensors in these vehicles and some of the most famous examples was to meet some of these regulatory standards which I think as consumers a lot of people don't understand. Tell us a little bit where are those standards being pushed forward the most just so we understand in the global sort of picture. Yeah, so I think traditionally Europe has been leading when it comes to safety standards and safety regulation and automotive and euro and cap is a very well-renowned body that provides kind of incentivizes OEMs to invest in safety by given them safety scores and that can be used as a kind of a marketing element for OEMs that want to brand themselves as a safe car and the safest car. So every couple of years euro and cap publishes a new set of features or a set of use cases that in order to get the highest rating you need to comply with and that continuously pushes the bar of what is considered the best in class and in if you look at 2028 or 2728 onwards it's really a significant leap in what will be required. And we believe that this is another driving force for broader adoption of advanced features, level 2 plus, level 2 plus plus and combining with the fact that with days technologies we can make this in a very cost efficient way can really make this a very compelling argument because you know regulatory bodies do not want to create a standard that is impossible to comply with unless you make the car twice as much in price. So it's always a balance between like the upside of bitter safety versus what could it mean on consumers that will now need to spend more. Right. Right. And then when you're putting in hardware, that's where a lot of the cost of this comes from and you have to put it into meet a regulatory standard but then it unlocks other convenience features or things like that then you can take something that might just be sort of a cost to meet a compliance standard and actually offer them features that are more appeal. Right. It's not just meeting that regulatory standard. Yeah. So maybe if I can take a step backwards and kind of recap our portfolio and the different products from the lens of a consumer, you know, what will it mean on drivers? Not just regulatory bodies or not just systems and engineering aspects but for consumers for the everyday user, what would it mean on the experiences that I can have in a car? So again, starting from entry ADAS which is basically providing alerts, warnings to prevent dangerous things. This is what's the standard today like emergency braking, collision warnings and so on. From that point, there is like this surround ADAS which is basically as a driver, you're still driving most of the time, you're so responsible and yet in certain primary roads, you can take your hands off. So you can think of it as another upgrade for cruise control, which is a very like convenient feature to use but it still has limitations today and this is like taking it a few steps forward which means the system can steer the car and it can also adapt velocity in a much more sophisticated way. So as a driver, you don't need to intervene and help it, you know, very frequently, if at all. And then the next product is what we call supervision is a point to point, hands off driving everywhere. So basically as a driver, you enter the car, you're select your destination and the car takes you from point A to point B autonomously but still you need to be eyes on. Okay, this is like being a pilot in a commercial plane today, roughly speaking, you still need to supervise what's going on but again, the stress and load of driving is much lower on you. From that point, we have chauffeur which is kind of the crown jewel of our portfolio and has the highest promise I think for consumers because it's the first scalable product that offers time back to drivers. And this is for eyes off driving. The first first launch will be for highways and intercity roads. So again, imagine the user experience or enter the car, you select the destination and then once you enter the highway, you can take your eyes off it, you can mind your own business, you can do other things. That is a dramatic improvement and change in value proposition to consumers. And our roadmap is to launch this in two years, roughly speaking. And the leading program is without it, it will be offered in the US and Europe. So it's a very big milestone for us. And then finally, our final product is mobile iDrive which is designed for robot axes and kind of enabling mobility as a service. It's designed for fleets. So you can deploy this on a fleet of cars and then operate a robot axis service in a certain city, certain area. And this is kind of a very, very broad spectrum of products but we are, this is in the core mission of the company today. Yeah, no. And I love as someone who's spent a little time on the public education side of this. I love the, there's a simplicity to the hands off, eyes off way you describe it. You're not talking about levels of automation. You're not having people look up the J-30-16 standard for that, you know, I find that very refreshing because I think, you know, I think you need to put it in those terms of what a consumer is actually going to experience for them to understand it because they don't know what the numbers mean, right? Yeah. And I think that if you think about how consumers have been experiencing transportation in the past two decades, it's mostly through safety, comfort, time, and cost. And in these four axes, in safety, you can, you can say that we have made very good progress. You know, there's today a much better answer for safety incidences in cars and cars are safer today, you know, statistically you can prove it. But still, where it's far from a solved problem, you know, they're still more to do. Comfort, we've made maybe moderate progress. Still, you have features like cruise control that can be activated and some people use it, some nuts, but still practically the experience that you have in a car is practically the same as it has been two decades ago. The cost is pretty much the same, so it's not that new technologies have inflated significantly the price of cars, but in time, we have made if anything negative progress, I think that people today, you can argue, spend more time wasting more time in a car than they have been. So I think this is, this is a good way to understand where is the biggest opportunity, you know, the next two decades is, you know, getting from, you know, time waste to an efficient utilization of time and getting closer to completely diminishing or eliminating car accidents. That is kind of our future and our, you know, vision for the future. And we definitely believe that within the next few years, there will be a step function change in these parameters through our product launches. Yeah, so I want to dive into this because I think the the eyes off sort of vision, right? That has been, you know, we've had L2 L2 Plus for a while, there's sort of L2 Plus Plus, but and there have been companies who, OEMs, who've said, you know, we're going to bring, I quote unquote L3, right, an eyes off system to market, and they've had to kind of back off on this. This has clearly been a very challenging line to cross this from the hands off, right? There's a lot of different kind of ways and implementations. Getting to eyes off is clearly challenging. Talk to me a little bit about what makes that, that taking that step so challenging. Yeah, so I think that there is a, as you very well said, nobody argues about the potential value of having eyes off products. So the fact that we still don't have these products available in the market in a broad sense is not because it's not attracted. It's mostly because it's complicated. And the complexity comes from a very, very challenging balance between safety and usefulness that in order to make a useful product, you need to have a broad enough range of availability of the car. And if you want to support this broad range, while maintaining a very strict safety standard, then it creates a very complicated technological engineering problem. And you don't want to be optimizing just for one.
